        <b:widget id='HTML461' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #93c47d; font-size: x-large;"> See</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The ice terrain at the North Pole tends to be rather flat, though some interesting formations of snow and ice can be found. There's only one protracted sunrise and sunset each year (which will not be during your visit). Tour operators stick a sign pole into the ice, but that's unofficial and purely for photographic purposes.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Despite their name, polar bears don't usually venture this far north (preferring the southern "coastal" parts of the Arctic ice cap, with better swimming opportunities.)</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML460' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleDo" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #6aa84f; font-size: x-large;">Do</span></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br />There are few formal recreational opportunities at the North Pole. Each year, however, there is a marathon foot race called the North Pole Marathon organized by Polar Running Adventures.<br /><br /><br />Adventurous types may try searching for Santa Claus but it is highly unlikely you'll be able to locate him, even if the blizzards which are common in most areas happen to clear for a while. That hasn't stopped the Arctic Circle city of Rovaniemi, Finland and the nearly-Arctic Interior Alaskan city of North Pole from promoting themselves as Santa's home; a few points further south also use North Pole or Santa Claus to promote Christmas-themed attractions.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleBuy" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="font-size: x-large;"><br /><span style="color: #93c47d;"> Buy</span></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">There are no shops at the North Pole; you should bring everything that you might need for your expedition.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

Celebratory caviar is traditional upon arriving at the Pole itself.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleDrink" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #6aa84f; font-size: x-large;"> Drink</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The North Pole's ocean-formed ice contains salt, making it unsuitable for drinking, even when thawed. BYOB. Celebratory champagne is traditional; vodka at -40° while standing on an iceberg is also quite appropriate.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleSleep" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #93c47d; font-size: x-large;"><br /> Sleep</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Although there are no permanent accommodations at or near the Pole, temporary camps can be set up, providing heated shelter for one or more nights. Barneo has semi-permanent heated shelters, which are commonly used by expeditions spending more than a day on the ice. See travelling in cold weather.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML455' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="NorthPoleConnect" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #93c47d; font-size: x-large;">Connect</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Any system based on geosynchronous satellites (which, relative to Earth, hover at fixed points above the equator) will not work, as they drop below the horizon near 80°N. This line corresponds to the middle of Ellesmere Island in Canada and northern Svalbard.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Iridium satellite phones are the only ones that will work, and they should work excellently since the poles are where the orbits of every satellite overlap. Globalstar will not, as its satellites can only relay to a nearby ground station, of which there are none close enough to the North Pole.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="TropicsDestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"><br />Destinations</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn forming the borders of the tropics and the Equator bisecting it are often local attractions — not the only reason for traveling to that part of the world but probably worth checking out if you're in the region. Here are some destinations on or near these latitudes:</span><br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span id="TropicsDestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Tropic of Cancer</b>: Ad Dakhla, Aswan, Muscat, Ahmedabad, Bhopal, Dhaka, Comilla, Jianshui, Guangzhou, Shantou, Chiayi, Todos Santos, Mazatlan, Ciudad Victoria, Exuma and Long Island (Bahamas)</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span id="TropicsDestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Equator</b>: São Tomé, Kasese, Entebbe, Kisumu, Meru, Pontianak, Galapagos Islands, Quito, Macapá</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span id="TropicsDestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Tropic of Capricorn</b>: Rehoboth (Namibia), Toliara, Darwin, Longreach, Rockhampton, Antofagasta, Concepción (Paraguay), Maringá (Paraná), Londrina, Sorocaba, São Paulo/Guarulhos, Cairns, Daintree National Park</span></span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="TropicsSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> See</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">In the tropics you can experience jungles, steppe and deserts and vegetation and animal life typical to these environments. Overall tropical areas tend to be the most biodiverse in the world. When hearing the word "safari", the first thing you think of is probably a tropical environment.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="TropicsStaysafe" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Stay safe</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">On the downside, the biodiversity also includes plenty of poisonous or otherwise dangerous animals and plants, as well as tropical diseases spread in various ways. Another risk is the sun and heat; the world's highest levels of UV-radiation can be found in high-altitude tropical locations, so always protect your skin in when outside in daylight. Finally, tips for travel in developing countries applies to almost everywhere in the tropics.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br />The Arctic is the area around the North Pole, including the Arctic Ocean and nearby land.<br /><br />The Arctic is formally defined as either the area within the Arctic Circle (at 66°33′46.7″ N), or all northern areas normally colder than 10°C (50°F), year-round. The latter definition includes inland areas south of the Arctic Circle, and excludes some areas north of it. Unlike Antarctica around the South Pole, the Arctic is sea covered in a floating ice sheet surrounded by dry land. In Antarctica the situation is exactly reversed.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>

Sweden</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>5</b> Murmansk — largest city in the Arctic and important military harbor, Russia</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>6</b> Norilsk — second largest city in the Arctic, access is restricted due to mining and military activities, Russia</span></span></li></ul><b><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>7 </b>Nuuk — capital of Greenland</span></span></li></ul></b><b><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>8 </b>Rovaniemi — the capital of Finnish Lapland</span></span></li></ul></b><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>9</b> Salekhard, Russia — a prosperous oil and gas-town</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>10 </b>Tromsø – historically a starting point for many Arctic expeditions and one of the biggest cities so far north, Norway</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>11</b> Utqiaġvik — the northernmost town in the USA</span></span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML406' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticOtherdestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Other destinations</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>1 </b>Dalton Highway — Alaska's highway to Arctic Ocean</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>2</b> Lofoten — one of the most beautiful areas in Norway</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>3</b> Northeast Greenland National Park — the largest national park in the world</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>4 </b>North Pole — there's not much here, as – unlike the South Pole – it sits on ever shifting sea ice</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>5</b> Pallas-Yllästunturi National Park — one of Finland's best national parks</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>6</b> Quttinirpaaq National Park — Canada's northernmost national park</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>7</b> Severnaya Zemlya — the last archipelago on earth to be discovered, in 1913</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>8</b> Svalbard — you're in luck as you won't need a visa getting there (though you might need one to get to Norway where almost all flights here depart from</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>9</b> Wrangel Island — the last wooly mammoths lived on this desolate island some four thousand years ago</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>10</b> Putoransky Nature Reserve — almost two million hectares of pristine nature in an isolated mountain range</span></span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML405' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticUnderstand" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Understand<br /></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Arctic is antipodal to Antarctica. And to get this out of the way: Polar bears: Arctic. Penguins: Antarctica and other places in the Southern Hemisphere. Both: Nowhere but zoos.</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><br /></span></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Within the Arctic Circle, the sun stays above the horizon during parts of summer (Midnight Sun), and beneath the horizon during parts of winter (Arctic/Polar Night).</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Anywhere north of the Arctic Circle is suitable to see the Midnight Sun in Midsummer (all summer if close enough to the poles) – unless a hill is covering the view – and most of the accessible Arctic is good for seeing the Northern Lights during winter.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The sun is low also when seen, 47° above the horizon at noon in Midsummer at the Arctic Circle, 23.5° at the North Pole. There are few truly warm days and temperatures below freezing (32°F or 0°C) are possible even in the summer. Winters are extreme in many areas.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The climate differs significantly by latitude – but also by longitude. Due to the Gulf Stream (from the Sargasso Sea), Scandinavia has a much warmer climate than Alaska, Northern Canada or Siberia at the same latitudes.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">In contrast to Antarctica which is terra nullius, virtually all dry land in the Arctic is national territory. </span></span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

        <b:widget id='HTML404' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticTalk" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Talk<br /></span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">English is the dominant language at international expeditions. Besides national languages (English, Norwegian, Swedish, Finnish and Russian) there are several indigenous languages such as Greenlandic, Inuktitut, and the Sami languages. People in the Nordic countries are famously excellent at foreign languages and many Canadians speak a bit of the other national language of their country, even though full bilingualism is rare. Russians rarely speak anything but Russian. Speakers of indigenous languages increasingly speak the metropole language and often another one, too.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML403' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<br /><span id="ArcticGetin" style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Get in</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Regular flights to most towns – and regional flights also to many minor settlements. Some towns, such as Murmansk, have connections by rail, and some regions have decent road connections. Many railways were built with mining goods, not people in mind, so you may be in for a slow and bumpy if usually picturesque ride. There are even four EuroVelo cycling routes to the Barents Sea (to Nordkapp and Kirkenes).</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The only guarded borders in the Arctic are Russia's border to Finland, Norway and USA, and the Alaska-Canada border. You should still check formalities.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML402' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticGetaround" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Get around</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Scheduled transportation through the Arctic is limited, and travellers need to rely on chartered or private vehicles in most areas. Many places – even what qualifies for cities so far North – are only accessible by boat or plane and even that may be possible only seasonally. Prices tend to reflect that, even where direct or indirect subsidies keep a service alive that would otherwise not be commercially viable.</span><br /><br /><br /></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Arctic Europe is generally significantly easier to get around in than Arctic Asia or North America.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML401' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">See</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Northern lights</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Whale watching — in regions of the seas that are not frozen</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Midnight sun — in the northern parts of the Arctic, the sun does not set for most of the summer (of course, the downside is that it doesn't rise in the winter)</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Ice and snow — in many parts of the Arctic, ice and snow is present year-round.</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Eurasian wildlife or North American wildlife</span></span></li></ul><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Polar bears</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Polar bears, Ursus maritimus, live in and around the Arctic Ocean. During winter, they can be found on and under the rim of the Arctic ice cap, hunting ringed seals in the water. During summer, part of the ice melts, and they retreat to land for a lean season.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">This huge habitat area contains only about 30,000 bears. Luckily, they tend to be concentrated in a few coastal areas where it is possible to see them, particularly in the summer and fall.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>1</b> Churchill, Manitoba, Canada. Known as the "Polar Bear Capital of the World". Churchill is a small village on the coast of Hudson's Bay, a branch of the Arctic Ocean. Every fall, Churchill hosts the world's largest concentration of polar bears, as the bears wait for the bay to freeze over. This has made Churchill a major tourist destination, as tourists board "tundra buggies" (large elevated armored buses) to go out and see the bears face to face. Churchill (Q744553) on Wikidata Churchill, Manitoba on Wikipedia (updated Jun 2017 | edit)</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>2</b> Wrangel Island, off the northeast coast of Siberia (and very hard to get to). The world's largest concentration of polar bear maternity dens. Wrangel Island (Q106594) on Wikidata Wrangel Island on Wikipedia (updated Nov 2017 | edit)</span></span></li></ul><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">In captivity, polar bears can be seen in zoos worldwide.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>History</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Sir John Franklin's 1845 lost expedition perished trying to map the Northwest Passage from the North Atlantic to the Bering Strait. Between 1903 and 1906, Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen was the first to complete the journey.</span><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>3</b> Gjoa Haven, southeast coast of King William Island, Nunavut, Canada. Amundsen stayed in what he called "the finest little harbor in the world" for nearly two years.</span></span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="ArcticEat" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Eat</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Traditional cuisines rely heavily on fish and meat (including seal and whale in many places), vegetarians beware. Most other food has to be imported from the south, so prices tend to be high. There are still e.g. berries growing locally, some of which may be new acquaintances.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

Despite the cold temperatures you can get sunburn too, especially when snow and ice are reflecting the sunlight. Sun on snow can cause snow blindness.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br /> The islands of the Indian Ocean are a varied collection, including many of the smallest territories and one of the largest island nations (Madagascar). Many hug the coastlines of continents; others must be sought out hundreds of miles from any other land.<br /><br />The one thing they have in common was being affected by the tsunamis of Krakatoa in the 1880s, and on Boxing Day 2004, in both cases ranging from remarkable waves to inundation.<br /><br />The subantarctic islands south of 45° latitude are categorized on this site as islands of the Southern Ocean, rather than islands of the Indian Ocean.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML361' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">The islands of the Caribbean Sea or West Indies are an extensive archipelago in the far west of the Atlantic Ocean, mostly strung between North and South America. They've long been known as a resort vacation destination for honeymooners and retirees and are a major area for cruise ships, but a small movement toward eco-tourism and backpacking has started to open up the Caribbean to more independent travel. With year-round good weather (with the occasional but sometimes serious exception of hurricane season in the late summer and early fall), promotional air fares from Europe and North America, and hundreds of islands to explore, the Caribbean offers something for almost everyone.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML360' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanCountriesandterritories" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Countries and territories</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Cuba, Jamaica, Hispaniola (shared by the Dominican Republic and Haiti) and Puerto Rico, often grouped as the Greater Antilles, are by far the largest islands in the area and the most visited by travellers. The Caribbean also includes the Lucayan Archipelago to the north, which is comprised of the Bahamas and the Turks and Caicos Islands, and the Lesser Antilles, a group of much smaller islands to the east.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br /><b>  Bahamas</b><br /><br />Archipelago of islands and cays surrounded by coral reefs off the coasts of Florida. One of them was the first piece of American soil Columbus put his foot on.<br /><br /><b>  Bermuda</b> (Outside of image map, see dynamic map)<br />Small and wealthy British overseas territory in the Atlantic, known for a type of shorts and the supposedly mysterious triangle.<br /><br /><b>  Cayman Islands</b><br />Known for offshore banking, and a great diving destination.<br /><b><br />  Cuba</b><br />The largest Caribbean island-nation, marked by decades of socialist government.<br /><br /><b>  Jamaica</b><br />An island of tall mountains, birthplace of reggae and a Commonwealth Realm.<br /><br /><b>  Haiti</b><br />Founded by former slaves who won their freedom and then independence against the might of revolutionary and Napoleonic France. Today, having struggled against conflicts and natural disasters, Haiti has relative political stability and security, and is again becoming attractive for those seeking a road less traveled.<br /><br /><b>  Dominican Republic</b><br />A fast-growing economy with some of the oldest colonial cities in the hemisphere.<br /><b><br />  Puerto Rico</b><br />A United States territory with bustling nightlife, as well as great inland sceneries.<br /><br /><b>  Lesser Antilles </b>(Anguilla, Antigua and Barbuda, British Virgin Islands, Guadeloupe, Montserrat, Saba, Saint-Barthélemy, Saint Martin, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Sint Eustatius, U.S. Virgin Islands, Barbados, Dominica, Martinique, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Trinidad and Tobago)<br />Small islands facing the open Atlantic. Many of them are dependencies of other countries.<br /><br /><b>  Leeward Antilles</b> (Aruba, Curaçao, Bonaire)<br />Also known as the ABC islands, these islands off the coast of Venezuela are associated with the Netherlands.<br /><br /><b>  Turks and Caicos Islands</b><br />Fabulous beaches and offshore banking.<br /><br />Other areas include:<br /><br />Navassa Island - Administered by the United States but also claimed by Haiti, special permission from the US government is required to visit, and access is difficult and hazardous.<br /><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">San Andrés and Providencia - Colombian territories off the coast of Nicaragua. These remote, off the beaten path destinations primarily cater to Colombian tourists.<br /><br />The Florida Keys are geographically adjacent to the Caribbean, and have a similar environment. South Florida is home to a large Caribbean culture.<br /><br />Belize, French Guiana, Guyana and Suriname are often considered part of the Caribbean as they share a common cultural heritage.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>

Trinidad</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>4</b> Reserva de la Biosfera Sierra del Rosario in Pinar del         <b:widget id='HTML357' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanUnderstand" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Understand</span><br /><br /><b><span style="font-size: medium;">History</span><br /></b><br /><br /><b><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Bermuda Triangle</span></b><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Since the 1950s, popular mythology created a large triangle in the Atlantic Ocean between Bermuda, Puerto Rico and Miami, an area in which ships and aircraft would apparently disappear. Explanations have ranged from alien abductions to methane bubbles from the seabed. It is generally regarded as a complete myth, with shipping and air traffic frequently traversing the area with no issues at all.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Caribbean Islands were first inhabited by the Arawak Indians, then were invaded by a more aggressive tribe, the Caribs. Neither could appreciate their victory forever, although the Arawaks may have had a quiet reign of nearly two millennia. With the arrival of the Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, French, Danish, and British, the Carib population steeply declined due to various factors, although the inhabitants today have been proven to still possess significant Carib heritage. The islands have known many historic battles and more than a few pirate stories. Unlike the Central American mainland, which was colonized almost exclusively by Spain (with English protectorates on the Caribbean side), the Caribbean has seen various colonizers, who sometimes fought hard over control of relatively minor islands, primarily because the Caribbean was a very profitable place to grow the cash crop sugarcane with slave labor. Ultimately, slavery became untenable due to uprisings like the Haitian revolution, which succeeded in achieving abolition of slavery and independence in one fell swoop, and due to the increasing moral qualms of the European colonizers themselves. Following the abolition of slavery, the British, and later the Dutch, French and Spanish colonizers brought indentured Indian labourers to the Caribbean to work on the plantations instead. As the rest of the world industrialized, many Caribbean nations fell behind because the plantation owners were unwilling or unable to invest their considerable wealth in industry and today most of those islands live from agriculture, the export of raw materials and tourism. Some territories have also found success as "tax havens" or as a destination for casino tourism (e.g. Cuba until the 1950s) due to laxer laws than in the U.S. or other nearby nations.</span><br /><br /><br /><b><span style="font-size: medium;">Culture</span><br /></b><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">While Spanish influence is strong in many parts of the Caribbean, indigenous, African and non-Spanish European influences are strong or even dominant on some islands. While most of the Caribbean is nominally Christian, indigenous and African rites have been blended with some tenets of Christianity to create new and unique belief systems. There are also many adherents of the Yoruba religion — called Santeria and Vodun — that came to the Americas with enslaved Africans. Some islands have substantial Hindu or Muslim minorities or both, while small Jewish communities on several islands including Curaçao are among the oldest in the Americas. Jamaica is famous as the wellspring of the Rastafarian religion.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Caribbean is known worldwide for its African-influenced music, including charanga in Cuba; merengue in the Dominican Republic; ska, reggae and dancehall in Jamaica; and calypso in Trinidad and Tobago. And of course there are the steel pan performers on quite a few islands. But this only scratches the surface of what you can hear on a trip to the Caribbean.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Climate</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">In general the climate of the Caribbean is tropical with little change in temperature over the course of the year, however, rainfall does vary by season and there is also a pronounced hurricane-season with a handful of major tropical storms passing through the region each year.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML356' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanGetin" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Get in<br /></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>By plane</b></span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>From Europe</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Given the region's colonial past, there are plenty of present connections from many large European cities. The routes do change over time, but generally most islands can be reached via London Heathrow, Frankfurt Airport, Amsterdam Schiphol and Paris Charles de Gaulle.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>From the United States</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The proximity of the United States means that most islands have a connection. The region is best served by Miami International Airport, but there are also flights from many large airports including those based in New York City.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>From Canada</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Major Canadian airports have direct flights to the region, albeit in lower volume than the United States.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Canada did not participate in the embargo on Cuba by the United States, so flights were possible from major Canadian airports long before the U.S. reestablished scheduled flights from U.S. airports to Cuba.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>From Central America and South America</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">There are flights from many Latin American countries to some islands, albeit not as comprehensive as from the United States.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Some Caribbean Islands actually belong to South American countries such as Venezuela and Colombia, and connecting through the capital city is possibly the best way to reach them.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">It might be easier to get to Cuba via a connection from a Latin American country, since many have friendly relations with the government there.</span><br /><br /><b><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">From the rest of the world</span></b><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">There are a few direct flights from major cities in Asia (e.g. China to Cuba), but it is probably best to find a connection between your city and either Europe or the United States to make your journey to this region. Australia and New Zealand may find a rare connection through Latin America however it will be comparatively expensive, with the United States providing more options. Travel from Africa is likely best served with a connection in Europe. Major airport hubs for access to the region are Miami International Airport, Florida and Tocumen International Airport, Panama.</span><br /><br /><br /><b><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">By boat</span></b><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Cruise ships are an alternative for getting into the Caribbean. Largely catering to visitors from the US, probably the most popular starting points for Caribbean cruises are Miami and Key West, though there may be cruises starting from the Yucatán Peninsula and Venezuela too. As cruise ships often spend the Northern Hemisphere summer in the Mediterranean and the winter in the Caribbean, they may offer transatlantic cruises to or from the Caribbean depending on the season.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The only regular passenger ferry from the mainland to a Caribbean island is operated by Baleària Caribbean and runs daily between Fort Lauderdale, Florida and Freeport, in the Bahamas.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Caribbean destinations are also popular among those who sail their own vessel.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML355' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanTalk" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Talk</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">English, Spanish, Dutch and French respectively are spoken on various islands, depending largely on its former colonial power. However, the majority of the population might not speak the metropole-version of said language but rather a creole, which often incorporates a lot of words from other languages (usually African and/or Native American) and can sometimes differ so much in grammar and spelling as to be unintelligible to even native speakers of the European language the Creole is based on.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The well-educated upper class and those who work in the tourism industry will usually be able to speak a version of the national language closer to what European visitors are used to, and they will often be able to hold a conversation in one or several other European languages as well. However, the likeliness decreases the further you get away from big cities and major tourism hot spots. As most of the Caribbean has a long history of both slavery and racial discrimination, and Creoles arose with that background and still sometimes have a stigma attached to them, you should be extremely cautious not to say anything negative about the Creole languages, their speakers, or their intellectual background. Believe it or not, political tracts and works of literature have been written in various Caribbean creole languages for centuries now, and to give just one example, the Jamaican Patois of Bob Marley is just as capable of expressing complex topics as are any American or British pop songwriters. Code switching is also pretty common and many people can be heard effortlessly switching from one idiom into another depending on the social situation, speaking "broad" Patois with friends or family and a much more metropole-sounding variant with tourists or in formal situations.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML354' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> See</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="color: #8e7cc3;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Quelle Soufrière?</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">When the French colonizers gave names to places in the Caribbean, they apparently lacked imagination when it came to volcanoes. You can namely find a volcano named Soufrière ("sulfur place" in French) on Guadeloupe, Montserrat and St. Vincent and Grenadines. On Dominica, Haiti and St. Lucia it is the name of a town. Most of the Caribbean being geologically active, you probably won't have to travel far from these towns to see some...soufrière.</span></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Caribbean Islands are famous for the "3 S's" Sun, Sea and Sand, which you can find plenty of in the region. There are all kinds of beaches from touristy ones with plane or shiploads of tourists to exclusive and expensive private islands, and of course places popular with locals. Some famous beaches include the Seven Miles Beach in the Cayman Islands and the Arashi beach and Baby Beach in Aruba. Traditionally (beach) tourism to this part of the world has been about resorts, cruises and package trips, but independent travel is certainly also possible.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">While the indigenous heritage has all but disappeared, apart from the small remnant of the Carib people, who live in Dominica, the oldest colonial cities of the Americas can be found in the Caribbean. Perhaps no surprise as this was where Columbus and other Europeans first set foot in the New World, and several islands are still dependencies of France, Netherlands or the UK. Indeed, many of the world heritage sites in the Caribbean are colonial old towns, including ones in Havana, San Juan, Curaçao and the English Harbour.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Back then, the Caribbean Islands also became a major destination for Africans that the colonizers forcibly brought in to work as slaves. The enslaved people lived under inhumane conditions with hard work, violence, disease and starvation making up their daily life. Slavery is long gone; some former plantations have now been turned into memorials, for instance the Slave Huts on Bonaire. Black and mixed people make up a majority of the population of the Caribbean today, and the local culture has African influences, including the voodoo religion of Haiti, the carnival and various styles of Caribbean music and dance.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Natural attractions (other than beaches) include rainforests, volcanoes and other geologically interesting features such as the Boiling Lake in Dominica. Other interesting mountains include the pitons in Saint Lucia (pictured on their national flag), and Pico Duarte in the Dominican Republic, which is the highest point in the Caribbean.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Just traveling around the Caribbean can be exciting too, whether you do it by boat, plane or road. On Saba, you can land and take off on the world's shortest commercially used runway.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanDo" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Do<br /></span><br /><b><span style="font-size: medium;">Sports</span><br /></b><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Two closely related sports that are popular in the Caribbean are baseball and cricket. Baseball is very popular in much of the Spanish-speaking Caribbean, while cricket is the more popular sport in the English-speaking Caribbean.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Caribbean is also known for its sprinters in atheltics, with Jamaica and the Bahamas in particular regularly producing a large number Olympic gold medallists.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanEat" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;"> Eat<br /></span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Local cuisine is usually very well seasoned whether the outcome be savory, sweet or spicy. Don't be afraid to ask about what you're eating but be open minded when patronizing rural eateries where the cuisine is not tailored for international palates. The not-so-secret ingredient in much of the Caribbean (including the Caribbean coast of mainland Central America) is coconut and you may be surprised by the huge variety of foodstuffs that can be improved by the addition of coconut.</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Many Caribbean countries also have large Indian communities due to the fact that many indentured labourers were shipped here from India to work on the plantations instead following the end of the Atlantic Slave Trade. As a result, Indian-influenced dishes like curries as flatbreads are common in countries which received a large number of these Indian indentured labourers such as Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="CaribbeanStaysafe" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Stay safe</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Natural disasters that may affect the Caribbean are hurricanes during the summer and autumn, and less frequently but anytime and usually without warning: earthquakes and volcanic activity.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The crime situation varies considerably between islands and you should refer to the article on each island for specific information. Most places do experience low level theft such as wallets and cameras from unsuspecting tourists. Homicide levels also vary greatly, from high levels such as in Trinidad and Jamaica to low levels such as Cuba and Bermuda. Many islands with high crime rates often have exclusive resorts where tourists can be kept safe in a luxurious setting, with the obvious disadvantage that you will not do any exploring or see much of the local culture.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br />The islands of the Atlantic Ocean are - except for those in one concentrated region - scattered far and wide, with little in common but their relative obscurity. On the other hand some of the islands below are very popular holiday destinations, more precisely, beach destinations.<br /><br />The most numerous group of islands are the so-called West Indies and their neighbors, located southeast of the United States of America, east of Central America, and north of South America. Although part of the Atlantic, this sea forms its own region: the Caribbean. On the other side of the ocean, the Canary Islands, Madeira, Azores and Cape Verde form an area known as Macaronesia.<br /><br />The near-polar islands to the far north and south are covered here among the islands of the Arctic Ocean and Subantarctic Islands.<br /><br />The remaining islands of the Atlantic run rather intermittently from the southwestern tip of Europe, past West Africa, across the equator, to the open waters of the South Atlantic:</span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Most of the Arctic consists of the Arctic Ocean, littered with islands, mostly fragments of the North American, European, and Asian continental masses. Some are inhabited; others are completely covered in snow and ice and therefore uninhabitable. Several of the most interesting lie in the border waters between the Arctic and northern Atlantic Oceans, 60° and northward toward the Pole.</span></p>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML322' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="IslandsoftheArcticOceanIslands" style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;">Islands</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><b>1 Greenland </b>— a vast self-governing territory of Denmark<br /><br /><b>2 Iceland </b>— the northernmost (or least-extended-to-the-south) fully independent nation on Earth<br /><br /><b>3 Jan Mayen</b> — home to a tiny Norwegian radio and weather station<br /><br /><b>4 Svalbard </b>— by far the most visited islands within the Arctic Circle, a territory of Norway<br /><br /><b>5 North Pole </b>— not actually an island, just a point on a vast shifting and floating mass of ice<br /><br /><b>6 ATOW1996</b> — northernmost known bit of land on Earth, north of Greenland<br /><br />Northern Canada includes many islands, the biggest of which are more than 1000 km across, as well as much mainland territory. A few islands include:<br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><b>7 Baffin Island</b><br /><br /><b>8 Cornwallis Island</b><br /><br /><b>9 Ellesmere Island</b><br /><br /><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Russia has an exceedingly long Arctic coast with a number of islands off it.<br /><br /><br /><b>10 Franz Josef Land<br /></b><br /><b>11 Novaya Zemlya</b><br /><br /><b>12 Severnaya Zemlya</b><br /><br /><b>13 New Siberian</b> Islands and a group north of them that includes Bennett Island<br /><b><br />14 Wrangel Island </b>– a national park and World Heritage Site</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML321' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="IslandsoftheArcticOceanUnderstand"style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;">Understand</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br />The largest number of Arctic islands are parts of the Nunavut and Northwest Territories of Canada, and several are part of northern Russia; most of these are barren and uninhabited, and are covered (to the extent they are covered) in their respective countries' articles.<br /><br />Greenland – so large it hardly deserves to be called a mere "island" – lies largely in the Arctic Circle. Although it is arguably part of continental North America, it bears cultural and practical similarities to its smaller neighbors in the Arctic region. Likewise, Iceland barely kisses the Arctic Circle and has a fairly mild climate, but still has a sparsely-vegetated landscape and moderate accessibility issues. Jan Mayen and Svalbard are quintessentially Arctic – remote and harsh – but habitable.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="IslandsoftheArcticOceanGetin" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Get in</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><b style="font-size: large;">By plane</b><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Longyearbyen in Svalbard, is accessible on regularly scheduled SAS flights from Tromsø and Oslo, Norway.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Reykjavík, Iceland, is served by several flights a day from other Nordic countries and from the United States.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Greenland is reached primarily by flights from Denmark and Iceland.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Nunavut, Canada is reached primarily by flights from Ottawa and Yellowknife.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML319' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="IslandsoftheArcticOceanGetaround" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Get around</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>By plane</b></span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Although they lie on or near the "great circle" routes taken by airliners between Europe and North America, the Arctic islands are generally treated as "fly-over" territories, with fewer stops since passenger planes gained the ability to cover the distance without refueling. Because of their historical ties to Europe, they are easier to get to from there than from Canada or the U.S.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Deutsche Polarflug</b>. North Pole and Svalbard sightseeing flights, starting in May 2007, 11-hour sightseeing flights departing from Germany in an Airbus 330, cruising over Norway and Svalbard, flying low over special sights, and getting all the way up to the North Pole. Most passengers switch during the flight between center-section seats to pairs of outer-section seats, giving everyone in this class a window or next-to-window seat for half of the flight; a small number of tickets are center-section or outer-section only. Informative in-flight programming. €790-€1190 economy, call for first-class.</span></span></li></ul><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>By tour</b></span><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Adventure Life</b>. Offering small-ship expeditions and land safaris to Arctic islands and the North Pole, their Arctic voyages have been featured in New York Times and USA Today.</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Arctic Kingdom</b>. Offering land safari tours to remote destinations in the Arctic. Luxury camping options including boat tours and polar bear watching expeditions.</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Big Five Arctic Tours</b> - Offers group and individual tours to the Arctic.</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Quark Expeditions</b>. Provides everything from month-long semi-circumnavigation trips to week-long explorations of the Arctic, including ice-breakers to reach the remote North Pole.</span></span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><b>Ocean Expeditions</b>. Expedition support yacht ‘Philos’ purpose-built for high latitudes. Specialising in private or commercial expeditions involving film making, scientific research, adventure activities, wildlife enthusiasts or just an intimate experience of the Arctic.</span></span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="IslandsoftheArcticOceanSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">See</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Arctic scenery varies throughout the seasons and depending on area. Travelers have opportunity to see an abundance of wildlife throughout the course of a cruise or land trip. Best times to go vary based on what wildlife viewing is preferred. From late May through early September one can see caribou, moose, humpback whale, beluga whales, seals, grizzlies, polar bears, Arctic foxes, muskoxen, and up to 200 species of birds. In the ice covered regions (such as at the North Pole) there is little wildlife.</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The Northern Lights may be visible at the highlight of the dusk and nighttime hours on a cruise.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><b>Islands and territories</b> tend to defy a tidy geographical hierarchy. On a planet covered 70% by interconnected oceans, in a literal sense every place is an island. But the really big ones we think of as continents, leaving the smaller islands – scattered far and wide – as the "leftovers" of geography, which often makes them some of the most unique and interesting destinations.<br /><br /><br />These articles group them for the traveler (sometimes bending official geography to do so):<br /><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Islands of the Arctic Ocean - near-polar territories north of 60°</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Islands of the Atlantic Ocean - islands in the east and south Atlantic</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Caribbean - the West Indies and more, a part of the Americas</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Islands of the Indian Ocean - island territories and nations, big and small</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">East African islands - including Madagascar and several smaller islands</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Islands of Oceania - islands found in the equatorial and southern regions of the Pacific Ocean</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Antarctic Islands and Subantarctic Islands</span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<p></p> <span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><a href="#EuropeRegions">Regions</a> - <a href="#EuropeCities">Cities</a> - <a href="#EuropeOtherdestinations">Other destinations</a> - <a href="#EuropeUnderstand">Understand</a> - <a href="#EuropeTalk">Talk</a> - <a href="#EuropeGetin">Get in</a> - <a href="#EuropeGetaround">Get around</a> - <a href="#EuropeSee">See</a> - <a href="#EuropeDo">Do</a> -<a href="#EuropeBuy">Buy</a> - <a href="#EuropeEat">Eat</a> - <a href="#EuropeDrink">Drink</a> - <a href="#EuropeSleep">Sleep</a> - <a href="#EuropeStaysafe">Stay safe</a> - <a href="#EuropeStayhealthy">Stay healthy</a> - <a href="#EuropeConnect">Connect</a></span>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML249' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br /><b> Europe</b> attracts more tourists than any other continent: over 600 million international visitors annually, more than half of the global market. Out of Earth's ten most visited countries, seven are in Europe, with good reason.<br /><br />Although Europe is not one country, the ease of crossing borders might make you think otherwise, and transport infrastructure is generally efficient and well-maintained. At the other end of a short ride on a starkly modern high speed train, a brief flight, or an easy drive, you will likely be able to delve into a new phrasebook and culture.<br /><br />Europe has cultural heritage dating back more than three millennia: the continent has seen the rise and fall of Ancient Greece and the Roman Empire, and birthed the Renaissance and the Industrial Revolution. Countless kingdoms, republics and empires have left archaeological sites and old towns galore, and the most magnificent cathedrals in the world for you to explore. Aside from history, Europe is the home of high culture, is renowned for its diverse cuisines, and is justly celebrated for its exciting and romantic cities.<br /><br />Europe stretches from the shivering Arctic Ocean in the north, to the pleasantly warm subtropical Mediterranean Sea in the south, and contains a vast array of temperate climates and variety of landscapes in between. The east of the continent is connected to Asia, and for historical reasons a boundary is usually drawn from the Ural mountains via the Caucasus to the Aegean Sea, while the continent's western extremities jut bracingly into the Atlantic Ocean.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML248' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="EuropeRegions" style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br />Regions<br /><br /><br /><br /><b>Balkans</b> (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Kosovo, Moldova, Transnistria, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Romania, Serbia)<br />A rich and often turbulent history, with wonderful nature, charming multicultural towns, impressive monasteries and citadels dotting the hillsides, and mighty mountains liberally sprinkled with beautiful forests and pleasant lakes.<br /><br /><b>  Baltic states</b> (Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania)<br />Fascinating states with glorious beaches along an extensive coastline, medieval towns, and beautiful natural scenery.<br /><br /><b>  Benelux </b>(Belgium, Luxembourg, Netherlands)<br />A largely flat area with a lot to offer. The Netherlands is known for its clogs, cheese, tulips, windmills, painters, and liberal attitudes. Belgium is a multilingual country with beautiful historic cities, bordering Luxembourg at the rolling hills of the Ardennes.<br /><br /><b>  Britain and Ireland </b>(Guernsey, Ireland, Isle of Man, Jersey, United Kingdom)<br />The United Kingdom has a patchwork of native and immigrant cultures, plus a fascinating history and dynamic modern culture, both of which remain hugely influential in the world. Ireland has rolling landscapes and characteristic customs, traditions and folklore.</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><b>Caucasus</b> (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, and the breakaway states of Nagorno-Karabakh, Abkhazia, South Ossetia)<br />The Caucasus is a mountainous region lying between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, part of the boundary between Europe and Asia. It is a dense, warm, friendly and generally safe region, with diverse landscapes and a wealth of ancient churches, cathedrals and monasteries.<br /><br /><b>  Central Europe</b> (Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Liechtenstein, Poland, Slovakia, Slovenia, Switzerland)<br />Germanic culture meets Slavic culture in this region that straddles east and west, with historic towns, fairy-tale castles, beer, forests, unspoiled farmland, and mountain ranges, including the mighty Alps.<br /><br /><b>  France and Monaco</b><br />France is the world's most popular destination and one of the most geographically diverse countries of Europe. Attractions include Paris, picturesque Provence and the Riviera, Atlantic beaches, winter sports resorts of the Alps, castles, rural landscape, and its gastronomy (particularly wines and cheeses), history, culture and fashion.<br /><br /><b>  Greece, Turkey, Cyprus </b>and<b> Northern Cyprus</b><br />With the most hours of sun in Europe, the Eastern Mediterranean is a haven for beach-goers, party-people and cultural enthusiasts alike, and is known for its rich and tasty cuisine.<br /><br /><b>  Iberia</b> (Andorra, Gibraltar, Portugal, Spain)<br />These countries are great destinations for their rich and unique cultures, lively cities, beautiful countryside and friendly inhabitants.<br /><b><br />  Italian Peninsula</b> (Italy, Malta, San Marino, Vatican City)<br />Italy has more history and culture packed into it than many other countries combined. The island of Malta offers ancient sites, scenic getaways and marvellous aquatic activities.<br /><br /><b>  Nordic countries</b> (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden, and the autonomous Faroe Islands and Åland)<br />Spectacular scenery of mountains, lakes, glaciers, geysers, waterfalls and volcanoes with opportunity for outdoor life, known for the Viking Age around AD 1000. Also known for being bastions of progressive politics with the world's highest tax rates and most comprehensive welfare states.<br /><br /><b>  Eastern Europe</b> (Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and the breakaway states of the Donetsk People's Republic and Luhansk People's Republic)<br />Russia is a vast country that spans all the way east to the Pacific Ocean. Ukraine is diverse, with a lot to offer, from the beach resorts of the Black Sea to beautiful cities. Belarus, sometimes called "Europe's last dictatorship", is the largest remaining Soviet-style country in the world.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>

          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="EuropeCities" style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;">Cities</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Amsterdam — canals, Rembrandt, hashish and red lanterns, the epitome of social liberal attitudes</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Barcelona — capital of Catalonia and home to Gaudí's famous Sagrada Família this place is much more than "Spain's second city"</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Berlin — scarred by four decades of division but experiencing an almost unprecedented boom, the capital of reunited Germany is one of Europe's most creative and innovative cities and still surprisingly affordable</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Istanbul — the heart of both the Ottoman and Byzantine empires, this bi-continental city is a bridge between east and west and Europe's largest</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">London — Europe's financial metropolis and the former heart of the British Empire, packed with all sorts of attractions from sports to museums and two millennia of history</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Moscow — the heart and brain of the largest country on Earth, Moscow has the heritage of both the tsars and the Soviets and all the other current or former occupants of the Kremlin</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Paris — the "City of Light" and one of the most visited places on Earth: romance, cuisine, the Eiffel Tower and a surprising amount of green await you</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Prague — home to Kafka and medieval emperors, this city has tons of well-preserved history as well as a vibrant nightlife to keep you fascinated</span></li></ul><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Rome — an empire was named after this eternal city of seven hills and today it is chock full of old and new, and even contains its own state, the Vatican</span></li></ul></span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>

        <b:widget id='HTML246' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="EuropeOtherdestinations" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Other destinations<br /></span><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Alps — both a barrier and a bridge for millennia, Europe's climate is formed by them and the continent's transportation funneled into their passes. This mountain range is also Europe's most beloved winter sports and hiking destination, as well as home to mythical mountains like Mont Blanc or the Matterhorn</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Białowieża National Park — the last and largest remaining parts of the immense primeval forest that once spread across the European Plain</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Cinque Terre — a gorgeous national park, which connects five picturesque villages</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Gotland — a sunny limestone island in the Baltic Sea with a legacy from the Hanseatic League</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Hardangervidda — a mountain plateau in Norway with astounding views of mountains and glaciers</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Mallorca — a Spanish island famous for seaside resorts, nightlife, and spectacular landscapes</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Meteora — six Eastern Orthodox monasteries built on natural sandstone rock pillars</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Plitvice National Park — beautiful turquoise-coloured lakes surrounded by a large forest</span></li></ul><ul style="font-size: large; text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Stonehenge — the well-known Neolithic and Bronze Age stone monument on Salisbury Plain</span></li></ul></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
