        <b:widget id='HTML66' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaCities" style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Cities</span></span></h1><div><span style="font-weight: normal;"><br /></span></div><div><br /></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Bogotá </span>— a city of contrasts with a hectic balance between the new and the old; the most cultural-minded of South American capitals</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Buenos Aires</span> — the city of tango and most cosmopolitan in Argentina</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Caracas </span>— full of theaters, malls, museums, art galleries, parks and well-conserved colonial architecture</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">La Paz </span>— built in a canyon, the highest national capital in the world</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Lima </span>— the sprawling, Pacific coast capital of Peru is a center of cuisine</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Montevideo</span> — the pleasant capital city of Uruguay, situated on the east bank of the Rio de la Plata</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Rio de Janeiro </span>— famous for its breathtaking landscape, its laidback beach culture and its annual carnival</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Santiago de Chile </span>— capital of Chile with many museums, events, theaters, restaurants and bars</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">São Paulo </span>— a hive of activity that offers a jovial nightlife and a diverse cultural experience</span></li></ul></span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML67' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaOtherdestinations" style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-weight: normal;">Other destinations</span></h1><span style="font-family: georgia;"><br /><br /><ul style="text-align: left;"><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">The Andes </span>– the world's longest mountain range, and the highest outside of Asia</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Canaima National Park </span>– its main attraction are the Angel Falls, at 978 m, the highest waterfall on Earth</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Easter Island </span>– an isolated Polynesian island famous for its mysterious history and giant stone statues</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Galapagos Islands</span> – isolated islands with unique wildlife: this is where Darwin saw the evidence for natural selection</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Iguaçu Falls</span> – breathtaking waterfalls on the border between Argentina and Brazil</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Machu Picchu</span> – high in the mountains, the lost city of the Incas is a spectacular set of ruins</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">The Pantanal </span>– large wetlands with diverse wildlife</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Salar de Uyuni </span>– Bolivia's seemingly endless salt flats</span></li><li><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Tierra del Fuego</span> – islands at the tip of South America, with rugged scenery, boat trips, and winter activities</span></li></ul><span style="font-size: medium;"><br />See also the sections on South America in the <span style="color: #cc0000;">UNESCO World Heritage List</span>.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML68' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaUnderstand" style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large; font-weight: normal;">Understand</span></h1><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br />History</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br />Before the arrival of the Europeans in the 16th century, the continent was home to different native American peoples, the most prominent being the Incas, whose empire stretched across much of the Andes, along the Inca Trails that are popular with trekkers today. Warfare and new diseases the colonizers brought with them had a negative impact on the native population. Eventually the entire continent was conquered by Spain and Portugal, with some other countries establishing colonies in the northeast, one of which - French Guiana still belongs to a European nation. The last indigenous polity to hold out was the Mapuche in what is now Southern Chile, who were only conquered after Chilean independence. As a legacy of this, virtually all of the continent is today either Spanish- or Portuguese-speaking, nevertheless, native cultures and languages are still alive in Bolivia and Peru, and the Guarani language is spoken today by many Paraguayans without any indigenous heritage whatsoever. The continent is also pretty diverse, with almost any ethnicity you can think of having a presence, including Jews, Afro-Latinos, people of Japanese descent (mostly in Peru and Brazil) and various combinations of European, African and Indigenous.<br /><br />Following a series of wars in the early 19th century, the colonies became independent and countries emerged largely in the form we know them today. The history of the continent has however not been without trouble, with (civil) wars, coups and periods of dictatorship occurring until the end of the 20th century. Nevertheless, as with North America and Oceania, South America was and to some extent still is a popular destination for immigrants, first from Europe and later on also from other parts of the world.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML69' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaGeographyandclimate" style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Geography and climate</span></span></h1><div><br /><br /><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Two prominent geographical features of South America are the Amazon rainforest and the Andes. South of the Tropic of Capricorn the landscape is savanna on the east coast and as a rule of thumb, it gets dryer the further west one goes. West of the Andes you can find the driest place in the world — the Atacama Desert. Patagonia, covering much of the southernmost 2/3 of Argentina and Chile is cool and dry with steppe and some forest, somewhat reminiscent of Central Asia or the North American prairie.<br /><br />Much of the continent is situated in the tropics and in these places the climate is defined by wet and dry seasons and constantly warm or hot temperatures (except for high-altitude locations in the Andes). The further south one goes, the more temperate the climate becomes and in Ushuaia (the southernmost city in the world) weather conditions are even reminiscent of coastal northern Scandinavia.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML73' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large; font-weight: normal;">Talk</span></h1><span style="font-size: medium;"><br /><a href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/File:Voseo_Buenos_Aires.jpg"></a><span style="font-family: georgia;">If you've studied "Spanish" Spanish, be prepared for some confusion<br /><br />Spanish is the official language in all countries except Brazil, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana, and is widely spoken even in the countries that are not historically Spanish speaking. The dialect varies between countries although all are noticeably different from the 'Castilian Spanish' standard found in Spain or the Mexican dialect taught to many students in the Southwestern US.<br /><br />Portuguese is the official language in Brazil, which comprises about half the population and land area of the continent. Note that the dialect is very different to that of Portuguese spoken in Portugal. Spanish and Portuguese are closely related and knowing one will provide you some basic communication ability in the other.<br /><br />In the border area between Uruguay and Brazil some people are fluent in an ad hoc mishmash of Portuguese and Spanish known as portuñol and it is certainly viable for crude communication if you don't speak the other language, though Portuguese speakers tend to have an easier time understanding Spanish than vice versa.<br /><br />Much like the English language, expressions and slang terms can change dramatically from country to country or even city to city. As words that have a totally innocuous meaning in one place can have a vulgar or "dirty" meaning elsewhere, it is good to do some research before using words like "coger" (meaning "take" in Spain, and a vulgar reference to sexual intercourse in most of Spanish America) or "bicha" (meaning "a line of people waiting" in Portugal, but a very derogatory way of referring to a gay man in Brazil) in the wrong context and possibly offending people or causing puerile snickering instead of getting a serious answer.<br /><br />There are also many indigenous peoples living in South America who speak their own languages, and if you are really going off the beaten track, you might have to learn them too. The most notable Native American languages in South America are Quechua (Bolivia and Peru) and Guaraní (80% of the population of Paraguay). In the Falkland Islands and Guyana, English is the official language, while in Suriname and French Guiana, the official languages are Dutch and French respectively.<br /><br />With the exception of Suriname, second-language English proficiency tends to be poor throughout the continent. That said, many people working in the tourism industry, as well as business people who regularly deal with foreign clients, speak a conversational level of English.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML70' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaCulture" style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><span style="color: #cc0000;">Culture</span></span></h1><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br />Football (soccer) is popular all over the continent, and it is often said that football is not just a sport but a religion. It is common to see children in rural areas and slums playing football in the street, and top level football matches often attract sold-out crowds. By far the most famous rivalry on the continent is that between the two giants of Brazil and Argentina.<br /><br />Linguistically and religiously, the continent is rather homogenous with Romance languages and Catholicism being the "norm" in almost all countries. In the latter half of the 20th century, American-style Evangelical Christianity and irreligion started making major inroads, the former mostly among the poor and the latter often among urban and university-educated youth. Pockets of indigenous religions survive though, and every winter solstice, the indigenous people in Cuzco, Peru re-enact the traditional Inca festival of the sun god, Inti Raymi.<br /><br />Peru and Bolivia are probably the best places to experience pre-Columbian culture with traditional dishes, clothing, handicraft and language still around together with attractions like Machu Picchu or Tiwanaku.</span><p></p></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML71' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<h1 id="SouthAmericaGetin" style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large; font-weight: normal;">Get in</span></h1><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><span style="color: #cc0000;"><br />By plane</span><br /><br /><br /><br /></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">Getting to South America has gotten much easier due to massive increases in flights to the continent by major global airlines. Although some particular places are still quite hard to reach (e.g. Paraguay, Suriname, northern Brazil), the places that you most likely want to go, such as Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro–Galeão International Airport, are more accessible than ever before.<br />From Africa: the only (reliable) options worth considering would be the South African Airways service linking O. R. Tambo International Airport with São Paulo - Guarulhos; or the Ethiopian Airlines service from Addis Ababa to Rio de Janeiro–Galeão International Airport and São Paulo - Guarulhos. There are also connections between Luanda and Rio de Janeiro, Salvador de Bahia and Recife with Taag Angola Airlines. Do realize that demand between Africa and South America is very limited, so even the aforementioned services are infrequent and fares may be quite high.<br />From Asia: Be prepared for a very long journey, especially if your itinerary includes connecting flights to travel to/beyond the major Asian and South American hubs. São Paulo - Guarulhos is the only destination with flights from the Far East. The Korean Air route between Seoul-Incheon and São Paulo - Guarulhos involves a stop in the United States (LAX) therefore it will require all passengers, including those in transit, to pass through U.S. customs and immigration. Air China flies to São Paulo from Beijing Capital via Madrid Barajas. From the Middle East there are some more alternatives; Emirates (Dubai), Etihad (Abu Dhabi) and Qatar Airways (Doha) all fly nonstop to São Paulo. Of these Qatar Airways continues down to Buenos Aires and Emirates has another line to South America — via Rio de Janeiro–Galeão International Airport to Buenos Aires.<br />From Australia, New Zealand, and the South Pacific: A somewhat surprising number of options exist. LATAM Airlines serve Auckland and Sydney from their hub at Santiago. Qantas introduced a non-stop service between Sydney and Santiago in March 2012, and Air New Zealand flies direct from Auckland to Buenos Aires. LATAM also operates one of the world's most obscure flights of all - a service linking Santiago-Easter Island-Tahiti. From Perth Emirates provides affordable flights to Buenos Aires with a stopover in Dubai, around 30 hours total flying time.<br />From Europe: The political, social, and economic ties between (former) colonies and their (former) metropoles remain strong. Portuguese flag carrier TAP Airlines is by far the leading foreign carrier to Brazil, serving a slew of destinations in North and East Brazil as well as the Brazilian capital Brasilia which otherwise have only limited or absolutely no other international connections. Spanish flag carrier Iberia flies to most of the former Spanish colonies, although neither Bolivia nor Paraguay are served. KLM flies between Amsterdam Schiphol and Suriname and Air France links Paris-Orly with French Guiana. Of course, such services are not exclusive - KLM also flies to Lima, TAP to Caracas, Air France to Rio de Janeiro–Galeão International Airport and Lima, etc. Other leading European airlines such as British Airways, Lufthansa, Swiss Airlines, and Alitalia also serve key South American gateways from their respective hubs, while South American airlines also operate into several major European cities as well. Air Europa also flies to many South American cities via their Madrid hub and connecting flights mainly across Western Europe.<br />From North America: Historically Miami airport has been the main gateway to South America from the US, however hubs at Atlanta airport, Dallas/Fort Worth, Fort Lauderdale, Houston, Benito Juárez International Airport, New York, Newark Liberty Airport, Orlando, Toronto, and Washington-Dulles offer viable alternatives, with airlines such as Air Canada, United and Delta Air Lines and American Airlines. American discount carriers such as Spirit Airlines and JetBlue now serve Colombia, Brazil and Peru. Latin American carriers such as Avianca, LATAM and Copa Airlines provide good hubs in the region.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML74' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaSee" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">See</span><br /><br /><br /><br /></span><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;">A sizable number of the world's largest, longest or highest natural wonders are located in South America. Perhaps the first thing you will notice when looking on a map of the continent is the world's largest rainforest, the Amazon, covering much of Brazil. Moreover it also features the world's largest wetlands, Pantanal, Angel Falls, the world's highest waterfall as well as the better known Iguaçu Falls. Other bodies of water worth mentioning include the Amazon river (by some measures the world's longest river and the one with the largest drainage basin), the world's highest commercially navigable body of water Lake Titicaca, and the wide Rio de la Plata (between Uruguay and Argentina) which is more like a bay of the Atlantic Ocean.<br /><br />In the west lies the "backbone" of the continent — the Andes. This mountain chain, which is the longest in the world, contains Aconcagua which at a height of almost 7,000 m is the highest mountain outside Asia. As the Earth is at its thickest at the Equator, the peak of Chimborazo (6,268 m) is the point in the world furthest away from the center of the Earth. Right next to these mighty mountains lays the Atacama desert which is the driest and possibly oldest in the world. The white spot that can be seen on satellite footage is the Salar de Uyuni. Located at 3,656 m above the sea level it is — you guessed it — the world's largest salt flat.<br /><br /><a href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/File:Capybara_(Hydrochoerus_hydrochaeris)_group.JPG"></a>The world's largest rodent species, capybara, is endemic to South America<br /><br />The Galapagos Islands, 1,000 km off the coast, feature an unique and fearless fauna (see Galapagos wildlife). There are several iconic and unique animals on the mainland too (see South and Central American wildlife), including llamas and other camelids, jaguars, capybaras, opossums and monkeys and on the other hand less pleasant creatures that are poisonous or spread tropical diseases. Another, equally famous island in the Pacific is Easter Island.<br /><br />While most people would think of South America as rainforest or desert, this is mostly but not entirely true — Los Glaciares National Park in southwestern Argentina will prove otherwise. Overall the climate and landscape of the far south actually recalls Norway or parts of Canada. Here you can find Ushuaia, the world's southernmost city and a gateway to Antarctica. South America also holds the record for the world's highest national capital La Paz, and at Chacaltaya you will find the world's highest located ski resort.<br /><br /><br /><br />It's certainly not only in modern times that people have lived and worked in the Andes even at altitudes where you are likely to contract altitude sickness. Particularly in Peru and Bolivia, you will find many beautiful and famous archaeological sites from the age before the Europeans, connected by pre-Columbian Inca Trails if you want to get around the traditional way. Among them the most famous is undoubtedly Machu Picchu, but places like Chan Chan and Tiwanaku are also deservedly inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Peru also features the Nazca lines, constructed 1500 years ago for an unknown purpose and only visible from air.<br /><br />The European heritage includes mining towns in the mountains, unsurprisingly a lot of churches and missions and other colonial architecture along the coasts. Of course, in places like São Paulo, Buenos Aires and Santiago de Chile you can also see skyscrapers archetypical to any metropolis in the world. And let's not forget about Rio de Janeiro with its world-famous beaches Copacabana and Ipanema with the Sugarloaf mountain, Pão de Açúcar, in the background.<br /><br /><a href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/File:Uniaodailha2014.jpg"></a>The carnival in Rio is the largest and probably most famous in the world<br /><br />South America offers a variety of cultural experiences. In the Andes, native traditions and languages still live strong. The east and south of the continent is more of a blend of cultures that immigrants from Europe, Africa and other parts of the world have brought with them; probably the best example of this is the Brazilian carnival.</span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML76' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaDo" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Do</span><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Tango in Buenos Aires, Argentina and Montevideo, Uruguay</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Travel the wilderness in a Jeep on the Salar de Uyuni, Bolivia</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Cycle down the Death Road outside La Paz, Bolivia</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Soak up the sun on the famous beaches of Brazil</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Explore the pristine jungle in the many nature reserves of the Amazon rainforest</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Bike through old Dutch plantations in Suriname</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Ski on the Andes in Chile or Argentina</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Experience a football (soccer) match anywhere in South America</span></span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><span style="color: #cc0000;"><br />Hiking</span></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /><br />As home to the Andes, the longest mountain range in the world, South America is a huge destination for hiking and trekking. The Andes are magnificent and breathtakingly beautiful, and their terrain varies from snowy peaks to stark passes to lush forests. Peru is probably the most famous trekking destination, including the world-famous Inca Trail and many lesser-known but equally rewarding journeys. Bolivia also has many popular peaks climbable by non-experienced mountaineers on tours, and a lot of unknown but equally beautiful 1- to 12-day hikes through the mountains and into the rain forest. Argentina and Chile, with their long Andean border, have a wide variety of hikes as well. In fact, almost every country on the continent has beautiful mountains with great hikes, the exceptions being low-lying Paraguay, Suriname, and Uruguay.</span></div>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>

  </b:if>

  </div>

  <b:include name='quickedit'/>
</b:includable>
        </b:widget>
        <b:widget id='HTML77' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaBuy" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Buy</span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Some national currencies experience volatility from time to time, in the 2010s most notably Venezuela, where the official exchange rate of the Bolivar is laughably disconnected from reality. In most countries the US dollar often used alongside local currencies, and prices of goods worth over a few hundred dollars may actually be quoted in US dollars.</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">In Ecuador, the official paper currency is the US dollar, while the government mints its own coinage, set equal to the US coins. In much of South America, US gold dollar coins are used commonly, and are often included in transactions.</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">With respect to Venezuela, the Bolivar fuerte is worth much less than its official value and you basically have to use the black market if you don't want your stay to become very expensive.</span><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">There is also limited use of euros (in French Guiana) and British pound sterling (in the Falkland Islands). Currencies other than US dollars tend to be of little use and hard to exchange outside their immediate area of use and adjacent border areas.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

        <b:widget id='HTML78' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaEat" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Eat</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;"><a href="https://en.wikivoyage.org/wiki/File:Ceviche_del_Per%C3%BA.jpg"></a>Peruvian ceviche — raw spicy seafood served with vegetables</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">South American cuisine is as diverse and colorful as its people. The continent's wide range of terrains brings forward a broad selection of food products and its many people all have their own ways of cultivating and preparing the land's goods.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">After the “discovery” of America, European settlers, African slaves and immigrants from other parts of the world all brought their own food traditions with them, adapting them to include local ingredients and cooking techniques. They also introduced a new set of meats, crops and spices to the culinary blend. The result is a most interesting mix of flavors. World-famous dishes include feijoada, ceviche, empanadas and of course Argentina's barbecued steaks. Widely used ingredients include corn, potatoes, chilli peppers and lima beans.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Less well-known in the rest of the world but much used by the indigenous people of South America are grains like quinoa and kiwicha, queso fresco (a fresh cow’s milk cheese) and yuca (also known as cassava). For a taste of traditional Andean meats, try alpaca or guinea pig (cuy - pronounced kwee). To top it all off, enjoy one of the many very sweet desserts, often combined with delicious tropical fruits that grow here.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->
  <b:if cond='data:title != &quot;&quot;'>
    <h2 class='title'><data:title/></h2>
  </b:if>
  <div class='widget-content'>
    <data:content/>
  </div>

  <b:include name='quickedit'/>
</b:includable>
        </b:widget>
        <b:widget id='HTML79' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaDrink" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Drink</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">South America offers a wide variety of drinks, some of which you can only legally consume in their country of origin (that would be coca tea, made from the leaf of the coca plant, supposedly a good way to combat the problems high altitude brings with it). Other drinks include yerba mate, a hot tea-like infusion, and Inca Cola, an alternative to the iconic American soft drink brand.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Keep in mind that coca leaves, sweets, beer, tea (bags) and other products are illegal in some countries in South America, including Brazil and Paraguay, and in the vast majority of countries outside South America. So be sure to get rid of any and all traces of coca tea or leaves before crossing international borders or otherwise leaving the few countries where coca is legal.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

  <b:include name='quickedit'/>
</b:includable>
        </b:widget>
        <b:widget id='HTML80' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaSleep" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Sleep</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">The types of lodging available are the same as in North America and Europe. For the backpackers the best option is hostel or camping. However, hotel rooms (like most other non-imported goods and services) are with a few exceptions rather affordable compared to North America and Western Europe. Pests are a risk if you are sleeping outdoors, especially in the tropical parts of the continent.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML81' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaWork" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Work</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Many countries have specific working needs, requirements and conditions (e.g. visa). Check each country individually.</span><br /><br /><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: medium;">Volunteering</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Working as a volunteer, learning Spanish and seeing the country on a shoestring is popular with many travellers in South America. Mostly people with lot of time opt for this kind of travelling, getting to know the country and its people.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Volunteering can be done as part of a large organisation, or for local families. When working with or for local families, they often provide you with food and accommodation for about 3-5 hr work per day. Such engagements can be found with any of the following websites, which differ by length and type of stay: Workaway, HelpX, Wwoof, and Worldpackers. The website generally demand a small commission or a yearly fee.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Use the rating system of these websites to determine good and reliable hosts. And beware, many locals just use those websites to find cheap labour, offering a terrible experience, sometimes no food or no decent accommodation. Avoid such offers, which are just badly managed businesses, and opt for placements that really depend on volunteers (like green farming, education, NGOs, etc.).</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Avoid paying for volunteering. You can also contact a bunch of international NGOs and let them know you are interested in working for them. Sometimes you can also get a paid job after doing some volunteer work. Just be clear that you are able to stay a fixed amount of time for unpaid work, and that you would need some money to continue your work.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

        <b:widget id='HTML82' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaCope" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Cope</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">You will find many other travellers in South America, often doing the same route as you. It is fun and useful to travel together with others; rent a car together to save money, hike together for a more secure experience, or just share your knowledge on the way about dangers, volunteering, secret gems, or any other valuable information. Relying on this information and help is useful and important, as can be seen with this travel guide.</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Facebook, for instance, has many local country groups available, like the Argentina &amp; Chile Backpacker / Traveler group and the Bolivia, Paraguay, Uruguay Backpacker / Traveler group where you can find other travellers and up-to-date information on the country. Also, hostels often have black boards available where you can sell and find stuff, or contact local travellers. Otherwise, just talk to the people that look like they need help or if you are trying to find help yourself.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

        </b:widget>
        <b:widget id='HTML84' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaStaysafe" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Stay safe</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">South America has some reputation for crime, including armed robberies, with Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela being noted as the most dangerous. Read up beforehand about the individual destinations you're planning to visit. As with anywhere else in the world, the right travel planning can mitigate any dangers.<br /><br />Wearing or carrying items which may identify you as an affluent tourist can be a mistake. You shouldn't pack anything that you would be upset to lose. Leave expensive jewelry, watches and other items of value at home and only carry what you need. That goes for credit cards and other documents as well; if you have no need for them leave them behind in the hotel safe, only take what money you are likely to spend with you.<br /><br />While tropical storms are rare, flash floods do occur in various parts of South America. Earthquakes and to some extent volcanic eruptions are a risk in the Andean countries, especially Chile.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>
          <b:includable id='main'>
  <!-- only display title if it's non-empty -->

  </b:if>

  <b:include name='quickedit'/>
</b:includable>
        </b:widget>
        <b:widget id='HTML75' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaStayhealthy" style="font-family: georgia;"><span style="color: #cc0000; font-size: x-large;">Stay healthy</span><br /><br /><span style="font-size: medium;">Tap water in many countries is not drinkable; it's wise to purify your own or buy bottled water. The countries with safe tap water are Argentina, Chile, and Uruguay. In Colombia, the tap water is drinkable in Bogotá, but it is not recommended to drink tap water in drier regions of the country.<br /><br />Malaria, dengue and yellow fever can be a risk as well on the continent, so check with a travel clinic or your doctor before heading out to see if you'll be in a high-risk area, and receive any vaccinations and medication required.<br /><br />The Andean countries include areas at high altitudes, making altitude sickness a risk. This is especially a concern in several popular destinations in Peru and Bolivia.</span></span>]]></b:widget-setting>
          </b:widget-settings>

        <b:widget id='HTML85' locked='false' title='' type='HTML'>
          <b:widget-settings>
            <b:widget-setting name='content'><![CDATA[<span id="SouthAmericaConnect" style="color: #cc0000; font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;">Connect</span><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br /></span></div><div><span style="font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;"><br />The reliability of postal services in South America tends to be iffy. If you have something important to send, it's wise to use a private company rather than the government-run services. Also, some countries' governments impose heavy import taxes or significant limitations on imports, which may cause problems if you or your friends back home try to send packages to the continent.<br /><br />Internet access is widespread, but speed varies. Government internet censorship is rare.</span><p></p></div>]]></b:widget-setting>

width=&quot;400&quot; /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: large; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Fireworks lit up the sky, crowds cheered and the island nation of Barbados officially became a parliamentary republic at midnight Monday, 55 years after its independence from the United Kingdom.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Dame Sandra Mason was named the first president of the country, which had announced in September 2020 it would step away from colonial ties, remove Queen Elizabeth as head of state and complete the process of transitioning to a republic.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The nation ushered in its new phase with singing, musical performances and an appearance by multi-hyphenate and Barbadian-born Rihanna, who was declared a national hero.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The ceremony was attended by Prince Charles, heir apparent to the British throne. In a speech commemorating the transition, he noted the legacy of slavery inflicted upon the island by the British.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;From the darkest days of our past, and the appalling atrocity of slavery, which forever stains our history, the people of this island forged their path with extraordinary fortitude,&quot; Prince Charles said.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;We the people must give Republic Barbados its spirit and its substance,&quot; Mason said in her address. &quot;We must shape its future. We are each other&#39;s and our nation&#39;s keepers. We the people are Barbados.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Barbados will stay part of the Commonwealth, a voluntary association of over 50 countries that retain some ties to Britain. Countries that still call the queen their head of state include Australia, Canada and Jamaica.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;NPR&#39;s All Things Considered spoke with Mackie Holder, consulate general of Barbados in New York, on whether this may push other countries to make similar moves. Listen here.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;Other Caribbean countries certainly will follow. Whether that will happen in six months, in a year &#8212; who knows? But I expect as we go further into the 21st century that we will see some changes and among other countries in the Caribbean as well,&quot; Holder said.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;Landmark Abortion Case Goes Before US Supreme Court&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/a/AVvXsEgZnad1jZQ_z3YPSF9dhzeus7WqNqJ8S8k4aIrgCMy9LoYkV3t8b17S8zaCNOoRe5_4D7ILCnfbM7gciDCtVh1gDgXgLr9M056eFNDJCi79Z2K3RC6k4agKbRoCRAHD4_YjAo2V3nYHQKP555VglKJh35iI67TYTYziKv4vqyFXCzwxUyxxLuGnJoZe=w400-h215&quot; style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;an abortion rights advocate holds signage at the Capitol&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;NEW ORLEANS &#8212; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Activists and concerned citizens on both sides of America&#8217;s generations-old battle over abortion have mobilized as a closely watched court case that could alter reproductive rights nationwide reaches a critical phase.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;On Wednesday, the U.S. Supreme Court will hear arguments on the constitutionality of a 2018 Mississippi law that banned abortion procedures in the southern state after the first 15 weeks of a pregnancy.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;How the conservative-leaning court rules could reinforce abortion rights across America or allow individual states to limit or potentially ban the practice.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In Mississippi, the epicenter of the case before the high court &#8212; Dobbs v. Jackson Women&#8217;s Health Organization &#8212; emotions are running high.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;I know women who have had abortions, and the decision is gut-wrenching for them,&#8221; said Matthew Burke, a Gulfport, Mississippi, resident who works for a nonprofit that rebuilds storm-damaged homes. &#8220;The decision is theirs to make, and now the supposedly highest court in the country might take away that right based on politics. It&#8217;s crazy.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Many others disagree.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;The idea of taking a life, no matter how young, breaks my heart,&#8221; said Danielle Rodriguez from Jackson, the state&#8217;s capital. &#8220;I think there are extreme instances where maybe an abortion should be allowed, but this law can help save children&#8217;s lives.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The Mississippi law at the center of Wednesday&#8217;s debate is the Gestational Age Act. Passed in March 2018, it was quickly blocked from taking effect by two federal courts that found the law to be unconstitutional. The Supreme Court will decide whether to uphold or reverse the decisions of the lower courts.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;That the Supreme Court even agreed to hear this case concerns those who support abortion rights, according to Mary Ziegler, a legal historian and law professor at Florida State University.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;They didn&#8217;t have to take this case,&#8221; she said, pointing to the landmark Roe v. Wade Supreme Court decision of 1973 that set forth a constitutional right to abortion in America. &#8220;The Supreme Court could have done the same as the lower courts and said Roe v. Wade already settled this. Instead, they&#8217;ve agreed to hear arguments, which might mean they feel they have enough conservative justices willing to overturn or reinterpret that decision.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;A unique moment in time&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In the 19th century, U.S. states began criminalizing abortions. Over time, more restrictive and punitive laws were adopted, eventually prompting Roe v. Wade, in which a woman successfully challenged a Texas state law that prevented her from obtaining an abortion.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Writing for the 7-2 Supreme Court majority in 1973, Justice Harry Blackmun noted &#8220;the sensitive and emotional nature of the abortion controversy&#8221; but concluded that &#8220;the right of personal privacy includes the abortion decision, but that this right is not unqualified and must be considered against important state interests in regulation.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;In 1973, the Supreme Court set the line at fetal viability,&#8221; Ziegler noted. Viability refers to a fetus&#8217; ability to survive outside the uterus. It has been generally believed fetal viability begins at approximately 24 weeks, or roughly six months.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;The court decided a state must allow access to abortions until that point. But that was a different court than this one,&#8221; Ziegler said, referring to the Supreme Court&#8217;s current 6-3 conservative majority. &#8220;(Former) President Trump nominated three conservative justices, and as a result, we haven&#8217;t had a Supreme Court this conservative in a very long time. It&#8217;s hard to guess what they&#8217;ll decide.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Backing for Roe&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Mississippi has been at the forefront of the debate since 2018 when the Gestational Age Act was passed. Billboards trying to sway public opinion line highways, while talk radio and social media have amplified the discourse.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Some hope the Supreme Court will follow the lead of the lower courts and find the act unconstitutional based on the precedent set by Roe v. Wade.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;I think the Supreme Court&#8217;s original finding that the right to an abortion is protected by the Fourth Amendment&#8217;s &#8216;right to privacy&#8217; is the correct one,&#8221; said Evan Ash, a student living in Oxford, Mississippi. &#8220;I think any woman who wants an abortion should be able to get one. Let&#8217;s hope this court sticks with that thinking.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Many of the act&#8217;s opponents worry it will endanger the lives of women. According to the Guttmacher Institute, a research group that supports abortion rights, the average distance a Mississippi woman would need to drive for an abortion would grow from 125 to more than 600 kilometers if the law goes into effect, as they would need to travel out of state to reach a clinic.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ash believes women of color will be disproportionately impacted if the Mississippi law is upheld.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;Mississippi is the Blackest state in the country, and our public schools aren&#8217;t even allowed to teach proper sex education, only abstinence,&#8221; he said. &#8220;It&#8217;s this huge cycle that creates an inordinate amount of teen pregnancies and children that can&#8217;t be cared for, which creates more poverty.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ash added, &#8220;Without access to legal abortions, I&#8217;m worried women, desperate, will risk more dangerous methods (to terminate pregnancies).&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Rights of the fetus&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Others argue for the rights of the unborn and for establishing those rights earlier in a pregnancy. While the case before the Supreme Court originated in Mississippi, it has prompted a deluge of television advertisements elsewhere in America, including the nation&#8217;s capital, where presumably the justices who will decide the case might watch them.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;By six weeks (in a pregnancy), we can detect a heartbeat with ultrasound technology. By 15 weeks, they (fetuses) can feel pain,&#8221; said an ad sponsored by the Susan B. Anthony List, a nonprofit anti-abortion group. &#8220;The scientific data that Roe v. Wade was based upon is antiquated.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The ad, narrated by a physician who opposes abortion, continues, &#8220;The case going before the Supreme Court from Mississippi to place limits on late-term abortion is absolutely necessary. &#8230; We have a responsibility to stand up for the vulnerable and those who can&#8217;t speak for themselves.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;The thing I think liberals get wrong about many of us that are pro-life is that we&#39;re not against the woman carrying the baby,&#8221; said Jackson, Mississippi, resident Danielle Rodriguez. &#8220;We&#39;re just passionately for protecting the baby they&#39;re carrying.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Possible outcomes&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ziegler doubts the Supreme Court will find the Gestational Age Act wholly unconstitutional.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;They&#8217;ve surprised us before, but why would they accept the case if they&#8217;re going to make the same decision the court made 50 years ago?&#8221; she wondered. &#8220;It&#8217;s likely some change is coming.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Whether that change means a complete overturn of Roe v. Wade, reducing the time period in which states must allow access to abortions from 24 weeks to 15 weeks, or some other form of restriction remains to be seen.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ziegler said the court might opt for incremental change now, setting the stage for a more sweeping transformation of reproductive rights in a future case.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;I think the justices are very aware of optics right now,&#8221; she said. &#8220;They prefer to be seen as above politics, but they understand they are being viewed cynically by many Americans at the moment. I wouldn&#8217;t be surprised if they were careful with this decision before they do something broader on abortion in years to come.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Polling data&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Gallup polling earlier this year found 32% of respondents believe abortion should be legal in any circumstance, 19% believe abortion should be illegal in all circumstances and 48% believe abortion should be legal under certain circumstances. Such data fluctuates from year to year, but a nation divided on the question of abortion has remained constant.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Should the Mississippi law survive Supreme Court review, other Republican-led states stand ready to enact restrictive abortion laws. That America could one day have a patchwork of abortion laws that vary widely from one state to another does not bother abortion opponents.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;The Constitution is clear on the rights of the state(s) versus the federal government,&#8221; said Denver Mullican, a resident of Natchez, Mississippi. &#8220;These are decisions for the individual states to make with input from medical experts.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;This isn&#8217;t an issue of state&#8217;s rights,&#8221; Ziegler countered. &#8220;This is an issue of human rights. If you believe access to abortion &#8212; even if it&#8217;s tied to some time frame benchmark &#8212; is a right women should have, then the Supreme Court is where this decision should be made.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;Islamic State Murders in Syria&#8217;s al-Hol Camp&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;November 29, 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;font-size: large; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;214&quot; src=&quot;https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/a/AVvXsEgwhK4kHcfMqDoGnNUxBwB-g3vogdVXrpQfZRnSVmFnurc-E00RFr5nSYF3q18n3QJUkdUUDoSzpXq8JbNiFwWHW3E_Hpmlq63azj4A-eXbKoMBNtCls-UPK1But8HW1FClGBqqEX3EQXDrabaXQ1REZxWeFVkP6o5qyd6g9rSGAbl3KQYvvY0Guaok=w400-h214&quot; width=&quot;400&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Most of the women we meet in al-Hol camp, a detention center in northeastern Syria, won&#8217;t talk about the murders. But Umm Mustafa, from Iraq, speaks quickly and quietly, standing away from the crowds in the market.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;She voices shock.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;It is not the roughly 80 killings so far this year in al-Hol that she finds shocking, but the people who have been arrested. Those believed to be responsible for the killings are women from the Hisba, the self-appointed Islamic State-styled religious police inside the camp.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;But it&#8217;s their right,&#8221; Mustafa explains, defending the military&#8217;s right to arrest members of the Hisba. &#8220;They killed people who work with the administration, so the administration arrested them.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Sharing information with the administration, meaning the guards, is considered one of the gravest sins against IS in al-Hol camp. The guards are members of the Syrian Democratic Forces, or SDF, a Kurdish-led military that is in large part responsible for the defeat of the so-called caliphate in Syria.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Al-Hol is now packed with more than 60,000 women and children &#8212; many wives and offspring of defeated IS militants. In some ways, they live now as they did when the group controlled large parts of Iraq and Syria, under their harsh interpretation of Islamic law. Disobedience is punished with violence.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;But Um Mustafa wants us to know not everyone chooses to live this way. The camp is locked and the only way out is to be released, transferred or escape.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;Everyone here has their own way to raise their family,&#8221; she says. &#8220;Don&#8217;t judge the whole camp by those people.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;Early days of al-Hol camp&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In 2018, al-Hol held 10,000 residents, mostly Iraqi refugees.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;But then came the battle for Baghouz, IS&#8217;s last stronghold in Syria or Iraq.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;As Baghouz fell, the camp filled at an astonishing rate. Tens of thousands of men, women and children fled aerial bombardments and relentless gunfire before surrendering to the SDF. They were IS fighters, their wives, children and others who lived under their rule.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The men were almost all imprisoned, and the women and children were transported to camps. Within months, al-Hol had more than 70,000 residents, mostly women and children. Most of the new residents were Syrian or Iraqi, but about 10,000 women and children were from dozens of other countries on six continents.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Back then, as is it now, the humanitarian situation was dire, and children died from harsh conditions and lack of medical support.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;At that time, however, there was an atmosphere of relief. The families were the survivors and many women we met were eager to talk about it. Some wanted to show their support for the caliphate, while others wanted to display their disgust, saying they were happy to be freed from the group, and the veils covering their faces.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Still others seemed confused. &#8220;My husband was a cleaner in a mosque,&#8221; one woman told us listlessly, hours before being transported to al-Hol. &#8220;Does that make me a terrorist?&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In one tent in al-Hol, a young mother told us that her religion required that we should be killed, but she would not do it. &#8220;Please, stay and have tea,&#8221; she added.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;Evolving camp culture&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;As the chaos of the battle for Baghouz died down in the months that followed, families settled into the drudgery of living in a squalid, isolated detention center. Ardent IS supporters among the women appointed themselves to be the Hisba, re-establishing the routines and rules they lived by under IS.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Residents started calling al-Hol &#8220;Little Baghouz,&#8221; and the brief time when you could walk into the camp and hear an array of open opinions or see women&#8217;s faces came to a halt.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Not long after that, intelligence officers at the camp started reporting killings, attacks on security personnel, tent burnings and hundreds of escapes. They said weapons and money were smuggled into the camp and that they lacked the capacity to secure it.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Many aid organizations were forced out by extremists, or just left. Camp administrators sent out pleas for help from the international community through journalists and nongovernmental organizations. The help they wanted never materialized, and dozens of countries ignored calls to take back their citizens.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Layla Rezgar, a camp official at that time, told us that she couldn&#8217;t understand the lack of outside concern. Members of one of modern history&#8217;s most brutal extremist groups were gathering weapons and attacking wherever they could. &#8220;Why isn&#8217;t anyone listening?&#8221; she asked.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;Extremism and sorrow&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In the two years since that conversation, the situation has only devolved. Besides ongoing violence, women in the camp appear increasingly despondent.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In late October, women mostly ignored our questions about life under IS before the camp, and Hisba rule now.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;I don&#8217;t want to talk about that,&#8221; says Umm Abdullah, a 26-year-old Russian woman. &#8220;I want to tell you my problems.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;A crowd soon gathers, and her problems appear to be shared by everyone within earshot. Her 13-year-old nephew was recently removed from the camp, and she wants to go home. Other women chime in, all outraged that boys aged 12 to 14 are being taken from their mothers without their consent, and without any warning.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Foreign boys are being brought to the Houri Center, a school for deradicalization, which doubles as a detention center. The boys were brought to Syria when they were small children, but unless their countries take them back, they will be transferred again to adult prisons when they turn 18.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;Where else in the world do people take children from their mothers?&#8221; asked a 40-year-old woman, from Xinjiang, China, whose 13-year-old son was recently removed. Like many other women in the market, she calls herself &#8220;Ayesha&#8221; when we ask her name.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Officials acknowledge the harshness of separating families, but say they have no better option if countries won&#8217;t take them back.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;Several days ago, some journalists went to the al-Hol camp and IS children threw stones at them,&#8221; says Farhad Shami, an SDF spokesman. &#8220;IS women enforce the IS laws, and women who break these laws are killed.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;Regrets&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;A few hours from al-Hol, in al-Roj camp, thousands more foreign wives and children of IS are reputed to be less radical.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Still, even there, children throw rocks and small bits of glass at visitors. Last month, 16 tents were burned in al-Roj, in what appeared to be a protest against the guards.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Many women leave their faces uncovered and make a point to wear more modern-looking clothes, like colored headscarves and baseball caps. Some women are willing to talk to reporters on camera, saying they hope if people see them on TV as human beings, not just IS wives, their governments might be more sympathetic.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;But nearly three years after the fall of Baghouz, says Merika Boudouaia, a 50-year-old French widow who traveled with her husband to Syria in 2014, it is hard to maintain hope that her teenage daughters will have any kind of future at home in France.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;I regret, I regret and I regret again,&#8221; says Boudouaia, weeping. &#8220;I have nothing now and I am tired. I am tired of this life.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;The omicron variant is cause for concern &#8212; but not panic, Biden says&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;November 29, 2021&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; src=&quot;https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/a/AVvXsEitFnUtyQprZebTU-OkClXutjrHWRs-iHKjph9MViJfEcIkY6d7hEBwqMTWGelYEsS0HEHjbUSBblGZpB47pyM_cnSG-L2q5vMemXY9mcGkJyu7ejiqVgAZzMQpfpmLGx6BDCZPnWREmvMCV1b-mTIDD_iwbrnjeH5ATmoVpIUCCGFrrWXocM2W_X_1=s320&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;O presidente Biden disse na segunda-feira que, embora as restrições de viagem impostas a viajantes de vários países da África Austral retardem a entrada da variante omicron do coronavírus, &quot;isso não pode ser evitado&quot;.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;Mais cedo ou mais tarde, veremos casos&quot;, disse ele em um discurso ao povo americano.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Biden acrescentou: &quot;Esta variante é um motivo de preocupação - não um motivo de pânico.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Ele reiterou seu apelo para que os americanos sejam vacinados como forma de se protegerem contra a COVID-19.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;A melhor proteção contra essa variante ou qualquer uma das variantes é se vacinar totalmente e receber uma injeção de reforço&quot;, disse ele.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Biden disse que os cientistas não acham que medidas extras serão necessárias para combater a nova variante, mas acrescentou que sua administração está trabalhando com os fabricantes de vacinas para desenvolver vacinas ou reforços contra o omicron, se necessário.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Ele disse que também irá direcionar a Food and Drug Administration e os Centros para Controle e Prevenção de Doenças &quot;para usar o processo mais rápido disponível, sem abrir espaço para a segurança&quot; para obter essas vacinas aprovadas e no mercado.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Ele disse que o consultor científico, Dr. Anthony Fauci, acredita que as vacinas atuais fornecem pelo menos alguma proteção contra doenças graves.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;O presidente descartou a necessidade de outro bloqueio para conter a propagação do Omicron&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;O comentário do presidente veio no mesmo dia em que as novas restrições a viagens de seu governo entraram em vigor em resposta à variante omicron.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;Estamos jogando tudo o que podemos contra este vírus&quot;, disse Biden.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Biden disse que o COVID-19 não pode ser derrotado até que o resto do mundo seja vacinado, e ele pediu aos países que têm vacinas em abundância que as forneçam àqueles que não as têm.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;Variantes delta, e agora a variante omicron, surgiram em outras partes do mundo. Portanto, não podemos desistir até que o mundo seja vacinado&quot;, disse ele.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;O presidente também descartou a necessidade de outro bloqueio para conter a disseminação do vírus.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&#8220;Se as pessoas forem vacinadas e usarem suas máscaras, não há necessidade de um bloqueio&#8221;, disse ele.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Questionado se ele espera que a propagação e a resposta à nova variante seja o &quot;novo normal&quot;, Biden disse que não e disse que espera que o novo normal seja &quot;todos acabam sendo vacinados&quot; e com uma injeção de reforço, e para reduzir o número de pessoas que não estão protegidas &quot;a um nível tão baixo que não vemos a propagação desses vírus&quot;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
