&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;Our Future On A Hotter Planet Means More Climate Disasters Happening Simultaneously&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;September 2, 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img border=&quot;0&quot; height=&quot;274&quot; src=&quot;https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/a/AVvXsEhun3-i5-MXt4vWsIrGrvL9skM2HEIaNJMZ1BFLNCrR0zIplubGN8EGtWqCRNfXkZf5PY_c12dVvHmmOfEVZGIqxOFqV74WkmzN17H4IxOspDwLv_v5fostrqQQIlU7Ro5Y1AjjwHkxbV6E0Up1W3EhAVd-c4jD512qGP8oOQVVl54NCS86ioCfiVmC=w400-h274&quot; width=&quot;400&quot; /&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;While the Gulf Coast and the Northeast struggle with flooding and power outages, it&#39;s easy to forget that wildfires are still raging in the West.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;It&#39;s a taste of a future when simultaneous disasters grow more common, according to the latest global report on climate science. Hurricanes, wildfires and torrential rain that triggers flooding are all amplified by heat, and the planet is getting hotter. Emergency managers are preparing for that future right now. They&#39;re hoping to speed up the pace of disaster response and also move people and critical infrastructure out of harm&#39;s way.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Craig Fugate, former administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, says it&#39;s clear to him that natural disasters are happening more often. &quot;I&#39;ve been doing this for over 30 years. I can remember when FEMA had really big disasters maybe every four or five years. Not every year. Certainly not multiple [disasters] in one year,&quot; he says.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Government statistics show that in the 1980s, there were fewer than four billion-dollar disasters driven by extreme weather annually, on average. The past five years have seen more than 12 such disasters each year. The damage totals are adjusted for inflation.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;That has happened as the planet has warmed by almost 2 degrees Fahrenheit compared with the late-1800s. Average temperatures could rise another 2 degrees by 2100, and even more if countries fail to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Scientists generally avoid blaming climate change for a specific event like Hurricane Ida, since similar hurricanes have also occurred in the past. The most recent report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change instead adopts the language of probability. It says, for instance, that rainfall so heavy that it used to happen just once every decade in the pre-industrial era is now likely to occur 30% more often, and 70% more often in a world that has warmed by 2 degrees Celsius, or 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit. The storms will also grow more intense.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The frequency of extreme heat waves could also jump more than fivefold, according to the report. Heat waves and drought can dry out the land, making it more vulnerable to wildfire.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Erin Coughlan de Perez, a researcher at Tufts University&#39;s Feinstein International Center, who also works with the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre, says emergency managers around the world are focused on that future. &quot;It&#39;s a big deal, right? If your job is disasters, and disasters are becoming more frequent, you&#39;ve got a problem.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;The first problem is simply shortages of people and money. Coughlan de Perez saw this a few years ago when a big flood was predicted for Bangladesh at a time when international aid agencies were focused on the war in Syria.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;People were saying, &#39;You know, you might have a forecast for flooding in Bangladesh, but we really can&#39;t divert our attention right now,&#39; &quot; she says. &quot;Which was really kind of scary. And you see this all the time.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Marlon Maldonado helps his wife and child into a boat on Aug. 31 in Barataria, La., to travel to their home after it flooded during Hurricane Ida.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Also, one disaster quickly disappears from the headlines when the next one hits. As a result, people who still need a lot of help getting back on their feet can feel abandoned. Fugate says that&#39;s a danger right now for communities in Louisiana that were hit by hurricanes just last year.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&quot;I was getting messages from people saying, &#39;I hope they don&#39;t forget about us. We have not rebuilt, and we still have places that haven&#39;t been repaired,&#39; &quot; he says.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Fugate and others say that the quickening pace of natural disasters demands changes in emergency response. For one thing, recovery efforts have to move faster, to keep up.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Samantha Montano, who teaches emergency management at the Massachusetts Maritime Academy, says that some aid currently gets slowed to a crawl by complicated paperwork that&#39;s supposed to prevent waste and fraud. &quot;Obviously that&#39;s important, but when those measures prevent people from getting the help that they need, then something is wrong and something needs to change,&quot; she says.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Even more important, they say, is acting ahead of time to get people and critical infrastructure out of harm&#39;s way. &quot;We&#39;ve got to reduce the impacts&quot; of extreme events like hurricanes, Fugate says. That can mean upgrading building codes, requiring sturdier buildings and, in some places, burying power lines. Those measures can be expensive. Persuading people to move out of flood zones can be painful. But Montano says such measures can avoid more pain down the road.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Extreme weather by itself isn&#39;t the problem, she says. &quot;It&#39;s when that hurricane comes ashore and meets a community that is living in poverty or doesn&#39;t have strong-enough building codes or doesn&#39;t have enough boats to do search and rescue &#8212; that&#39;s when it becomes a disaster,&quot; she says.&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;Coughlan de Perez says communities all over the world are trying to do this. But it&#39;s really hard to get ready for the dangers of a warming world &quot;because we haven&#39;t seen it, right? So our past understanding of the world, based on our lived experience, is no longer a good predictor of our current risk and our future risk.&quot;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;But with sea levels rising and hot summers turning forests into kindling, many people are realizing that places they thought were safe may now be vulnerable.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;High oil prices could chill Japan&#39;s traditional public baths&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;b style=&quot;font-size: large;&quot;&gt;Public baths, or sento, have long been a cherished part of life in Japan but their owners are facing a spike in prices for fuel that heats the boiler that feeds hot water into the tubs&lt;/b&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;TOKYO, Nov 26 - The COVID-19 pandemic didn&#39;t manage to kill off Dai-ni Takara-yu, a traditional Japanese public bath on a Tokyo back street where neighbours have soaked their cares away since 1949.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;But for third-generation owner Tokuji Ito, high oil prices are the next test.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;With the coldest months of the year upon him, he must pay 50% more than last year to heat the water for the tubs that are a cherished part of life in his neighbourhood on the western side of the Japanese capital.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;It&#39;s really hard,&quot; said Ito, 53. &quot;For a large company, it might not be that big a deal, but for a small, family-run place like us, it&#39;s really tough.&quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Public baths, or sento, traditionally served people who did not have a bath at home, with bathers scrubbing down in separate men&#39;s and women&#39;s sections before soaking in hot tubs. They have also been places to socialise.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ito eked his way through Tokyo&#39;s repeated waves of coronavirus states of emergency: sento were required to stay open, though the number of older customers at his fell by about one-third.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;But he now faces bills of 450,000 yen a month ($4,000) in January and December for fuel oil to heat the boiler that feeds hot water into the tubs, up from 300,000 yen last winter.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The price for the bath is fixed by the Tokyo government, so he can&#39;t charge more, though he says he wouldn&#39;t raise prices anyway.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;Just after the pandemic, we were hoping to get people back. So these high prices are difficult,&quot; he said.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Japan&#39;s public baths don&#39;t need any more problems. Their number peaked at 18,000 nationwide in 1968, but now there are only 1,964 after decades of social changes, including more baths at home. Many sento serve beer or have saunas to attract customers.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Ito hopes to tough it out until the warmer months, when less fuel will be needed. A former oil trader who returned to the family business five years ago, he thinks prices won&#39;t hit previous record highs.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;For now, customers still line up before the baths open at 3:30 p.m.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&quot;I don&#39;t mind even if he has to raise prices,&quot; said Shuji Yamazaki, 70, who comes three to four times a week. &quot;Without these baths, I&#39;d be in real trouble.&quot; (Reporting by Elaine Lies and Akira Tomoshige Editing by Peter Graff and Gerry Doyle)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;New Country, New Name for US Citizen &#39;Enes Kanter Freedom&#39; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; November 28, 2021 &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt; Boston Celtics center Enes Kanter is changing his name to &quot;Enes Kanter Freedom&quot; to celebrate becoming a United States citizen.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt; Kanter&#39;s manager, Hank Fetic, told the Associated Press that Kanter will have his citizenship oath ceremony on Monday afternoon and at the same time will complete his legal name change.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The news was first reported by the Athletic.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Kanter, 29, is a native of Turkey who has been an outspoken critic of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and the Turkish government. Kanter has said his passport was revoked by his homeland in 2017.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The 2011 first-round draft pick has also taken to social media to support Tibetan independence and criticize Chinese treatment of the Uyghur people. During games, he has worn shoes decorated to say &quot;Free Tibet&quot; and argued for a boycott of the 2022 Beijing Olympics.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;Travis Scott sued for over 1 million dollars after Houston tragedy &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;November 8, 2021 &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;A lawsuit was filed after the Astroworld Festival tragedy in which eight people were killed and dozens injured in Houston on Friday night, November 5th. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;According to CNN , an injured viewer during the festival is suing rapper and producer Travis Scott , who was the organizer of the Astroworld Festival, as well as entertainment company Live Nation, show promoter Scoremore and others involved. In the event. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In the lawsuit filed by Manuel Souza, it is read that he &quot;suffered serious bodily harm when the uncontrolled crowd at the show knocked him down and stepped on him&quot; and also says that &quot;the defendants failed to plan and conduct the show in a safe manner.&quot; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;The process continues: &#8220;Instead, they consciously ignored the extreme risks of harm to concert-goers and, in some cases, actively encouraged and encouraged dangerous behavior. His gross negligence caused the Claimant serious injury.&#8221; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Jury judgment is preferable to determine the exact amount of damages under the suit, but Souza asks for &quot;monetary reparation of more than $1,000,000.&quot; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In a statement sent to CNN, Live Nation, the company responsible for organizing the Astroworld Festival, wrote: &#8220;Heartbroken for the lives lost and those affected at Astroworld last night. We will continue to work to provide as much information and assistance as possible to local authorities as they investigate the situation.&#8221;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;All five continents have already registered cases of omicron and Botswana confirms another fifteen cases&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia; font-size: x-large;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;November 29, 2021&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: georgia;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Canada has already confirmed 2 cases of the omicron variant in the province of Ontario. As a result, all five continents register infections of this new strain.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;B.1.1.529 is considered by the World Health Organization as a &quot;variant of concern&quot; due to more than fifty mutations in its viral structure, 30 being in the &quot;Spike&quot; protein (The key to many vaccines to reduce disease symptoms ).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;Botswana has also updated omicron cases, with 15 new records. So far, 15 countries have restricted flights departing from southern African countries, with Israel fully closing its borders to foreigners for fourteen days.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;In Brazil there are no confirmed cases of this strain, but ANVISA reported yesterday afternoon that a person from South Africa tested positive for Covid-19. It is not known for sure if it is the new strain.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;
